1 Journal of Molecular Catalysis, 67 (1991) 91-104 91 Influence of surface support properties on the liquid-phase hydrogenation of propargyl alcohols on AIP04-supported nickel catalysts Felipa M. Bautista, Juan M. Campelo, Angel Garcia, Rafael Guardeno, Diego Luna* and Jose M. Marinas Department of Organic Chemistry, University of CorOba, E-14004 C6rOba (Spain) (Received June 13, 1990; revised February 6, 1991) Abstract Liquid-phase semihydrogenation of propargyl alcohols (2-propyn-l-ol, 3-butyn-2-of and 2-methyl-3-butyn-2-ol) has been carried out on nickel catalysts at 20 wt.% supported on three different AlP04, identical from a chemical point of view, but different in textural and acid-base properties. According to the results, the acid-base nature of the supports, through metal-support interaction effects, plays an important part in determining the specific catalytic activity of supported nickel catalysts. These metal-support interaction effects, as well as the methyl substitution effects on catalytic activity, can be evaluated through several isokinetic parameters obtained due to the existence of a linear correlation between the activation parameters Ea and in A (obtained from the Arrhenius equation) known as the 'compensation effect'. These isokinetic parameters are also linearly related to the surface density of acid and basic sites as determined by titration with pyridine and cyclohexylamine, acrylic acid and phenol, respectively. Introduction In recent years, the applicability of aluminum phosphates as nickel supports has been subject of several studies and patents [ 1-7]. In this regard, for a number of years we have conducted research on the synthesis and characterization of Pt, Pd, Rh and Ni catalysts supported on aluminum phosphates [8-12], as well as on their application in different hydrogenation or dehydrogenation processes [ 13-19 ]. Thus, the utility of AIP04-supported nickel catalysts in the liquid-phase hydrogenation of the olefinic double bond is closely related to the largest saturation ability of AIP04 supports for Ni metal, which promotes the greatest activity per unit weight of nickel metal when supported on AlP04 as compared to conventional supports such as A1203 or Si02 [11, 12]. Furthermore, the existence of metal-support interactions on these systems has been based on the kinetic behaviour of the catalysts [ 11, 12, 17 ] and on the suppression of hydrogen chemisorption [20], as well as with the help of a poisoning 'Author to whom correspondence should be addressed. 92 titration method [21 ]. The nature of this interaction between the support and the metal crystallites has not yet been clarified in detail, although there are several possible sources of these interactions [22] which include the epitaxial stabilization of preferred crystal faces, the transfer of electrons between the metal particles and the support, or a combination of both. The present paper reports an investigation into the support influence on the catalytic behaviour of Ni/AlP04 catalysts in the liquid-phase semihydrogenation of propargyl alcohol 2-propyn-l-of (P-yn) and its two methyl derivatives: 3-butyn-2-of (B-yn) and 2-methyl-3-butyn-2-of (MB-yn), the latter being an intermediate for an industrial synthesis of isoprene [23]. By using three different AIP04 as the support, all identical from a chemical point of view, but showing some differences in their textural properties and acidity-basicity balance, we could test the relative influence of the geometric and electronic effects of supports on the catalytic hydrogenation process. Thus, according to Bartholomew et al. [24], an electron transfer between the nickel atoms and acid sites on the support reduces the d-band concentration of electrons in the metal crystallites, leading to a catalytic behaviour more characteristic of cobalt. Thus a correlation between some kinetic parameters obtained from the hydrogenation reactions and the acid-base properties of the supports could be associated to electronic influence in the metal-support interaction effects, whereas such a correlation with the support textural properties would provide information on the role of geometric support effects. Experimental Catalysts The catalysts used were three AIP04-supported nickel systems previously described in the liquid-phase hydrogenation of 1-hexene [ 12 ]. These catalysts, containing 20 wt.% nickel, were prepared by impregnation of the supports to incipient wetness with 10 M aqueous nickel nitrate, following the procedure previously described [11, 12, 17]. They were dried, crushed and screened to a particle size < 0.149 mm (10 mesh size), reduced in an ultrapure hydrogen stream (1.7 cm' s-1) at 400 C for 4 h, and then cooled to room temperature in the same hydrogen stream and stored in sealed glass bottles until required. Aluminum orthophosphate prepared according to Kearby [25] were obtained by precipitation with propylene oxide from aqueous solutions of AIC13 - 6H20 and H,P04 (85 wt.%) at pH = 6.1 at the `precipitation end point'. The solid obtained (with Al/P=1) was then washed with isopropyl alcohol and dried at 120 C for 24 h. The resulting powder screened at 0.120-0.149 mm was calcined for 3 h in an electric muffle furnace at three different temperatures (500, 650 and 800 C). References to the supports will be made by the use of these numbers denoting the calcination temperature. These values were determined by a spectrophotometric method described elsewhere [27], that allows titration of the amount of irreversibly adsorbed acid or basic compounds employed as titrant agents of basic and acid sites, respectively. The monolayer coverage at equilibrium at 25 C, Xm (in Amol g-'), is accomplished by applying the Langmuir adsorption isotherm, and it is assumed as a measure of the acid or basic sites corresponding to the specific pKa of the base or acid used as the titrant. The metal surface area, SN,, of the three supported nickel catalysts was previously obtained [ 12 ] from the average crystallite diameter determined by X-ray diffraction according to the method of Moss [ 28 ] (Ni/AIPOQ-500 = 72, Ni/AIP04-650=87 and Ni/AIP04-800=18 m2 gNi-', respectively. Apparatus, materials and procedure Hydrogenation experiments were carried out according to the procedure described previously [ 11, 12, 17, 21 ] under vigorous shaking (300 strokes min-') in a conventional low pressure hydrogenator (Parr Instruments, Model 3911) equipped with a manometer that shows the actual pressure in the reaction vessel. The reaction temperature was controlled by pumping water from a thermostatic bath through the vessel jacket, at an accuracy of 0.5 C. The chromatographically pure alcohols (P-yn, B-yn and MB-yn) were used as supplied commercially (Merck, p.a.) after distillation under reduced pressure and low temperature. They were then passed through active acid aluminum oxide powder for chromatography (Merck) which was activated at 200 C in flowing ultrapure nitrogen. Methanol (p.a. 99% Panreac) employed as solvent and hydrogen (99.999% SEO) were used without further purification. 94 Most hydrogenation reactions were carried out in 25 ml of 1 M methanolic solution of substrate, with 0.3 g catalyst, under initial hydrogen pressure of 0.41 MPa and at a temperature between 20 and 60 C. Furthermore, one set of reactions was carried out with the Ni/AIP04-650 catalyst in the hydrogen pressure range 0.3-0.7 MPa, substrate concentration range 0.5-3 M, catalyst weight range 0.3-1 g and at various agitation speeds, in order to test the reaction kinetic orders and the absence of transport influences in the kinetic data, obtained under the present experimental conditions. The initial reaction rates were determined by taking the initial slope of the plot of the hydrogen pressure decrease at the manometer versus time. As these plots of the decrease of the hydrogen pressure with time were always linear (Mg. 1-A), the determination was straightforward and reproducible to within - 6ss'o. Kinetic results are expressed as specific areal rates, r,, in mol s-' MN;-', defined as the activity per unit surface area of nickel metal, in order to compare the activity of the different systems in terms of specific catalytic activity. They were obtained from the initial reaction rates and the metallic surface areas of catalysts. Hydrogenation runs were followed by GLC analysis of the reaction mixtures at appropriate intervals of hydrogen uptake (Fig. 1-B) to obtain a very low concentration of alkyne in order to determine the selectivity, S, from the relative concentration of alkene with respect to alkene and alkane [29]. The reaction product analysis was performed with a Hewlett-Packard 5830 gas chromatography fitted with an HP 3396A integrator, equipped with a column packed with 5ss'o Carbowax-20 M in 80/100 Chromosorb GAWDMCS. Neither isomerization nor hydrogenolysis products were detected in any of the cases. PH2 (MPa) mmol substrate 0.4 20 0.3 10 0.2 --v 20 40 60 20 40 (a) TIME (min.) mmol H2 (b) Fig. 1. Typical hydrogenation reaction at 40 C and standard conditions on Ni/AIP04-650: (a) dependence of hydrogen pressure on time in the consecutive hydrogenation of 2-methyl-3butyl-2-ol; (b) distribution of reactant and products as a function of hydrogen consumption: (O) 2-methyl-3-butyn-l-ol, ( ) 2-methyl-3-buten-2-of and ( ) 2-methyl-2-butanol. 95 Results and discussion Results obtained on checking the standard operating conditions indicate that kinetic data determined in the range of the studied operation variables are free from transport influences. Thus, the linear variation of the hydrogenation rate with catalyst loading and its independence with respect to the agitation speed above 200 strokes min-' allows us to assume the absence of external diffusion control. The average particle size of the catalyst used (< 0.149 nm) was such that the reactions were not influenced by internal diffusion, according to results previously obtained for allyl alcohols [ 17 ] under the same selected conditions. On the other hand, the independence of the hydrogenation rate from the initial hydrogen pressure as well as from the substrate concentrations in the studied ranges (0.3-0.7 MPa and 0.5-3.0 M, respectively) allows us to assume zero-order kinetics in hydrogen pressure as well as in substrate concentrations. This assumption is also consistent with the linear plots of the lowering of the hydrogen pressure vs. time [30] (Fig. 1-A). Results are thus identical to those previously found for the olefinic double bond of the corresponding allyl alcohols [ 17 ] and several substrates on supported nickel catalysts [11, 31-33]. Consequently, the mechanisms of the liquid-phase hydrogenation of double and triple bonds under the present experimental conditions must be very closely related. Otherwise, taking into account the zero-order kinetics obtained with respect to the substrate concentration as well as to the hydrogen pressure, the specific areal rates reported in Fig. 2 can be directly used as the reaction constant values to obtain the corresponding apparent activation energies, Ea, and Arrhenius constants, In A, collected in Table 2. The Eyring equation also evaluates the temperature dependence of reaction rates in terms of transition state theory by separating the enthalpy, OH*, and entropy, AS*, components. Their corresponding values, obtained by plotting In rAT-' against T-', are also shown in Table 2. In contrast to the catalytic activity, selectivity values, S, shown in Fig. 3, do not manifest appreciable modifications due to temperature effects because differences obtained are within experimental error. According to the results in Figs. 2 and 3, we can conclude that the calcination temperature of the AIP04 support does not produce important changes in either the specific catalytic activity or in selectivity. With respect to the effects of methyl substitution, while r, values clearly increase on increasing the number of methyl functions in the unsaturated alcohol in the sequence P-yn < Byn < MB-yn, the selectivity of the monomethyl-substituted propargyl alcohol, B-yn, is clearly lower. According to these results, not much information about methyl substitution effects or about metal-support interaction effects may be obtained from a direct correlation between these kinetic data, rA or S, and the corresponding values of textural or acid-base properties of supports. Thus, from (5) and (6): 102 PY O Ea In rA = 7.9 SBET - 20 SBET + R ( SBET + SBET - 1 - 21 (7) 717PY-160SBET 1034SBET -l807O T From the complexity of this expression emerges the difficulty in directly obtaining any correlation between catalytic activity and surface properties of supports. However, from the present results we should recognize the complex influence of these support parameters on the catalytic activity of supported nickel catalysts. Thus, according to (7), catalytic activity depends not only on textural and acid-base support properties but also on the kinetic parameter E8, directly related to the nature of propargyl alcohol and on the reaction temperature. This easily explains the different sequences obtained for rA values in Fig. 2 with different substrates on different catalysts at different temperatures. Conclusions On the basis of these results we may conclude that the density of surface acid and basic sites plays an important role in determining metal-support interaction effects on catalytic activity, in the liquid-phase hydrogenation of propargyl alcohols on AIP04-supported nickel catalysts. Thus, on increasing the surface density of support acid sites we might, in general, obtain an increase in the catalytic activity of the corresponding nickel-supported catalysts. On the other hand, on increasing the surface density of basic sites, the opposite is true. Consequently, the results obtained here are more in agreement with the prevailing role of an electronic transfer between support and metal than with a geometric support effect in determining the metal-support interaction effects. However, according to the influence of the BET surface area of supports, we cannot absolutely exclude some participation of geometric support effects in the catalytic activity of supported nickel catalysts. On the other hand, the existence of a 'compensation effect' or IKR allowed us to obtain such a complex relationship between surface properties of supports and the catalytic activity of Ni/AlP04 catalysts, through the existence of another correlation between the specific acidity and basicity of supports and the corresponding isokinetic parameters. Consequently, independent of the absence of a definitive theoretical explanation for this phenomenon [34-38], the LFER method, manifesting itself through isokinetic relationships in a series of related reactions, is still the most practical for predicting substituent effects for homogeneous reactions [29], and when applied to the catalytic heterogeneous processes, may constitute a promising technique for measuring the existence and extent of metal-support interaction effects. 103 Acknowledgements The authors gratefully acknowledge the subsidy received from the Comisi6n de Investigacion Cientifica y Tecnica (DGICYT, project PB89-0340), Ministerio de educacion y Ciencia as well as the financial support of the Consejeria de Educacion y Ciencia de la Junta de Andalucia. Liquid-phase semihydrogenation of propargyl alcohols (2-propyn-1-ol, 3-butyn-2-ol and 2-methyl-3-butyn-2-ol) has been carried out on nickel catalysts at 20 wt.% supported on three different AlPO4, identical from a chemical point of view, but different in textural and acid—base properties. According to the results, the acid—base nature of the supports, through metal—support interaction effects, plays an important part in determining the specific catalytic activity of supported nickel catalysts. These metal—support interaction effects, as well as the methyl substitution effects on catalytic activity, can be evaluated through several isokinetic parameters obtained due to the existence of a linear correlation between the activation parameters E a and ln A (obtained from the Arrhenius equation) known as the ‘compensation effect’. These isokinetic parameters are also linearly related to the surface density of acid and basic sites as determined by titration with pyridine and cyclohexylamine, acrylic acid and phenol, respectively.
